comments.commentBody:
And Mr. Brooks once again reinforces the gross misrepresentation being presented by the Republicans -- this time Mr. Ryan -- in asserting without further explanation or qualification that Mr. Obama "chopped" 700 billion from Medicare.

By comparison, his treatment of the Ryan-Romney proposals on the matter quickly devolves into gauzy spin that is at best equally misleading -- but tilting, naturally, toward his favored ideology.

In health care, the Democrats have a plan! Their cost savings is in the PPACA (Affordable Care Act) and is already showing great results. A major thrust targets fraud. Last fiscal year, the Attorney General announced a record annual recovery: $4.1 billion! In Feb., he brought the single biggest fraud case, taking down a network that bilked $375 million in illegal payments, going door to door to sign up phony recipients. No small change!

Another savings is currently the source of a misleading political attack. The President's plan creates $716 billion in savings (over 10 years) by eliminating overpayments and subsidies to Big Pharma—savings that Ryan wrongly insists is a "cut" in services. (It's not! It lowers the payment schedule for overpayments as high as 150%!, but does not cut services and will not “close” one in six hospitals as Ryan has claimed.) Under the Democrats, the care for Ryan's mother is preserved and extended by making it more cost effective.

Not in effect yet is the oversight panel which will monitor costs and best practices, setting adjustments to further reduce increases, a focus missing in the current system—or in Republican plans.

Social security has several easy fixes; raising the cap is the most obvious. It's fully solvent until 2038. These programs are earned benefits--not entitlements--tax payers have paid directly into the system and rightfully expect their benefits. (Debt interest, in some cases, is below zero!)

Liz,

Across Lite: The small window that opens in the center has 7 buttons on it. The one marked "Show hint" will show the hint.

Earlier in the evening I clicked my usual bookmarked link expecting to get Monday's puzzle but I realized upon completion that it was the August 3, 2010 puzzle. So I went to the NYT homepage, clicked the link that said crosswords, then clicked the link for today's puzzle which was still Monday's and got the correct one. I have now copied and bookmarked the latter link

http://www.nytimes.com/pages/crosswords/index.html?WT.mc_id=GM-D-I-NYT-T...

which differs from the one I have had bookmarked for weeks, and when I used it later in the evening I got the correct Tuesday puzzle. Go figure. Glad I was not the only one who thought she was in the Twinkie Zone.

Rohit,

Whether a woman has an abortion is none of your business. It is her decision and her decision alone.

Whether the USA kills children in foreign lands is your decision. Yours and every other citizen's.

Stop with the Republican "logic." It makes no sense.
Don't worry, Bryan, nobody is going to take away your Medicare, just the younger generations'. I hope you feel better now. As for the rest of your comment, the less said the better.

Believing that you went to law school seems about as inteligent as your choice of words like "whiz"
Not all of us are as man hating and lack the patience to use the womens bathroom, even if the line is long.
If these rich women REALLY wanted somewhere to golf then they ought to create their own private club and be selective in who they invite. Just like the othe commentor pointed out Spellman is all girls private, Curves is all female, Belizean Grove...secret and all female. Let the men have their spot!

Even though Fergie & Moyes appear to be close, Moyes isn't crazy enough to let Fellaini go, is he? He's much more elemental to their game than Arteta was. Who more than Fellaini (maybe Osman, Jagielka and Distin) personifies the Everton style? I wouldn't be surprised if Fergie tried to prise Baines away from Everton. If you recall, that was who I wanted Wenger to get from Everton last year, but we ended up with Arteta from Everton and Andre Santos at left back. Always talk of who is and is not a "Wenger type" of player. I think Baines would be an ideal bookend to Sagna on the left. I know it's never going to happen, and its only one match in, but I sure would like to see Dempsey leading the line at the Emirates. At his age, I think he's probably better off a center forward than an attacking mid, and with Arteta and Cazorla creating in MF, and Sagna throwing in crosses, he'd thrive. He's not RVP, but I have a sneaking suspicion he's better than Poldi. I saw some failure to follow plays to their conclusion with Poldi that I did not like, particularly the one where both he and O'Shea overran the ball in the Sunderland half, and Poldi made no move back for the ball. He needs to move-a lot, to prosper as an Arsenal center forward. Hopefully he'll cop on, or AW will pointedly instruct him to.
Fab will play more, only cause Xavi is a year older, and Iniesta often has knocks. Song? I honestly see him as half time. Why is Javi Martinez worth double Song?
e-mail: PaulandHelen@msn.com

With Rodgers favorite Joe Allen added, Charlie Adam, to quote Sparky Lyle, "Has gone from Cy Young to Sayonara."

Saw the Liverpool debacle at West Brom. Those center halves, with Carragher in reserve, don't appear to be the quality to get LFC to the Champions League. Two years ago, Skrtel was a nightmare, and last year he was great. He didn't impress. I think Agger's sending off was unnecessarily harsh, but other than Suarez and Gerrard, I wasn't impressed by anything Liverpool had in attack, and Suarez was a LOT better than Gerrard, who sprayed some inaccurate passes.
Liverpool never had a moment to match Gera's sweet strike

For Citeh, I thought Rodwell was very good, until he gave a weak pass away that ended up in Citeh's net after a break. Even though he's trouble, Tevez is still the best striking option at Citeh. But with Tevez, Balotelli and Nasri, they have changing room chemistry most likely to explode. With United up by 8 points with 6 matches to go, Citeh ultimately got out of jail to turn it around after a complete no show performance at the Emirates in crunch time. But does anyone remember United choking up a two goal lead @ OT in the last 8 minutes? And conceding 4 to Everton, 3 to Basel and 2 to Benfica and, of course, 6 to Citeh, all at OT? Even Arsenal, in one of the worst performances in team history, scored 2 at OT, and also had an RVP penalty miss, as well. United might be another major Vidic injury away from not competing for the league..

The criticism of Augusta National is not criticism of private clubs, per se. What you see is the public shaming of an organization that has made it clear that it sees itself as above the need to care about public mores. Look at what is happening to Rep. Akin from Missouri. No one is saying that he shouldn't be allowed to believe or say whatever he wants. But the mainstream society (including the Republican establishment) are shaming him because he has expressed an attitude outside the bounds of the current society's public morality.  Argue what you will, that you wish it had different mores, that you wish that it was still socially acceptable to be publicly racist or misogynist, but the truth is that the times change, and so do public mores, and Augusta National continues to willfully display its ignorance of where, and on exactly how fragile a pedestal, its (slowly but inexorably declining) public esteem rests.  Yes, one has ever right to have a club with as unevolved views and standards as the KKK. But a society whose mores has evolved, not only has the right, but it in fact cannot NOT heap public shame on offending organizations. (Shame is how a society shapes and self-governs itself). Few argue that the KKK should not be allowed to exist.  But no one argues that it should be granted any public esteem.
So the "doctors" Akin was referring to lived during the 13th century? Sounds about right.
And two of them are doctors....

Romney may be smart enough to disavow Akin.

But Akin's comments are mainstream Republican comments.
I shudder at the thought that this man and others like him could be running our government.  It's scary.
When the men of the republican party and the men of the Catholic Church experience what it is to be raped and pregnant, I'll be willing to hear them out.

Oops, the Easter Bunny is an innocuous holdover from pagan springtime fertility rites... The Easter Bunny actually represents biological truth compared to, for example, the Virgin Birth, as far as that goes...

"Mr. Akin, a member of the House science and technology committee..."

Has he found the same sort of sound scientific data to support the existence of the Easter Bunny yet?
And OB/GYN Ron Paul had "no comment"!
Oh well, I guess in their mind any medical background will do.  After all, they aren't talking about serious medicine anyway.

Of course: an ophthalmologist and a dentist. Those are certainly the experts you'd want to rely on in matters of reproduction. I'll bet they even have some unique contribution to make to the study of evolution.

This is not a different position for the Republican party, Ryan sponsored a similar bill in the House, that redefines rape.
"Paul Ryan is an original co-sponsor of the “No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act,” No abortion unless the woman seeking to terminate her pregnancy experienced a “forcible rape.”
http://thinkprogress.org/justice/2012/08/20/715731/obama-attacks-paul-ry...

Romeny should not look too far.  He has Paul Ryan.  He is no different in his beliefs than Akin.   It is hypocritical of Romney to denouce Akin and has PR as his running mate.  I don't see any difference between the philosophies of P Ryan an Akin.

Of course, Mr. Akin ought have every right to run for office as the democratically selected nominee and to raise funds to that end. Should the people of Missouri vote for him now the shame would be theirs.

In the most egregious act I have witnessed in politics, in the middle of a furor that had seen Karl Rove and the Republican Senate Campaign fund withdraw their financial support and other Republicans calling for his withdrawal, as even the waffling, milquetoast Mitt Romney issued two statements calling his words "wrong,"Todd Akin posted a request for funds on twitter, saying Missouri needed a conservative senator. The post including a url link to a website where donors could make contributions. His utter lack of shame should not be seen as strength; mercy should never endorse the sin.

Chris should check with the CEOs of hospitals before assuming they don't know how they will make money under ACA.  Many of the CEOs of the largest hospital groups have commented on the reduction in bad debt.  HCA for instance has bad debt running close to $4 billion annually and they project a massive reduction under ACA.  HCA, LifePoint, Community Health all had large increases in their stock price after the Supreme Court ruling.  This reflected a mirror of the increase when the ACA was first passed.  Less bad debt means more to the bottom line.  With more money there is more investment to handle even more services and then even more to the bottom line.  Nashville's largest industry is healthcare and is the nation's healthcare hub with over 450 healthcare companies, 300+ are national or international.  Over 60% of the nations for profit hospitals are based here.  Yes we tend to be well informed on the subject.

I think there is such justification. No respectable political group would tolerate the presence in its midst of someone with Akin's ideas, let alone allow him to be the party's standard bearer in the race for higher office, in this case the Senate..

His statement about abortion isn't his opinion, to which he would be entitled, it's a bald-faced lie with no basis whatsoever in fact. As a member of the Science etc. committee in the House he would be removed if he maintained that the earth is flat, and this statement about rape is just as unscientific and just as ignorant.

The Republicans have promulgated such lies and such extreme views as a part of their far-right strategy for a long time and they continue to get away with it - saying that abortion is dangerous (it's not, it's safer than having a baby), that it causes cancer (it doesn't) etc. They love this stuff as it pleases their far-right base. They ought to be ashamed.

Akin seems more outrageous than other Republicans, but he is one with Bachman, Santorum, Ryan, Gingrich and others - remember Sharron Angle - in taking extreme, unfounded views on abortion and related matters. I have not heard one Republican voice telling his/her colleagues to cool it on this issue. They're all in it together.

There is another article in today's times that says the official Republican party platform on abortion does not include exceptions for rape.Ryan co-sponsored a bill in the House that introduced the term "forcible" rape to the dialogue. So the idea that there are degrees of rape and that women should be forced to carry a rapist's baby to term are indeed Republican ideas.

Rather than saying "people like Akin," how about limiting his comment to him. This reporter went back a few decades and found only one or two such ill-informed people.
Is there any justification - other than political - to ascribe Akin's idiotic comment to any larger group (i.e., Republicans)? No.
But any nuns who say the same as Ryan or help save  a mother's life will be excommunicated post haste. After all abortion is a male issue.

In the aftermath of Akin’s “legitimate rape” comment, Romney/Ryan issued a statement that their administration “would not oppose abortion in instances of rape.”

Uh-oh.

The Republican candidates for Prez and Veep have contradicted the GOP’s own official platform. Tsk tsk. Will they be taken to task?

Nah.

More serious still, Ryan, that self-proclaimed Extremely Devout Catholic, contradicted the thunderous “no abortion exceptions” pronouncements of his own church. Will he be denied Communion by his parish priest? Roundly condemned from pulpits coast-to-coast? Threatened with excommunication?

Nah again.

Hypocrites.
The really scary thing is that the Republican Party is not incensed with the fact that Akin holds these views, but rather with the fact that he was so indiscreet as to publicly state them.

Well, these are the people who have placed all their thinking abilities and wisdom in the "hands" of an old man in the sky with a long white beard.  I have known otherwise fine Christian individuals who placed ALL responsibility for their their lives on the shoulders of God or Jesus or a Mormon prophet, and were constitutionally incapable of making informed, sound, and productive decisions for themselves.  This is what is meant by "praying for guidance" among these folks.  Magical thinking prevails.  When George W. Bush was photographed in deep prayer with furrowed, anguished brow in the Oval Office with his staff, I knew this country was in big trouble.

My own personal response is an overwhelming sadness that we have so many adults... and tragically among those who are ostensibly running the country who are so educationally deprived, so ignorant, so clueless, so cruel.
And consequently so socially irresponsible at a time that demands intelligence, wisdom, vision.
It's hard to be optimistic about the future of a country that elects people like Akins to represent us in high public office: an example of raising moral turpitude to a public virtue.

Norma Manna Blum

These views are, unfortunately, typical of the anti-choice GOP.

The Texas State Republican Party Platform states that the Republican Party wants to prohibit the teaching of critical thinking skills in public schools.

Facts have no place in their world view; just religious nonsense and fear.

According to his bio on his web site "Todd is a graduate of Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Worcester, Massachusetts, where he earned a B.S. in Management Engineering."

Can we see his transcript, please?

OK Ron, stay with them here: if a woman submits out of fear (gun, knife, etc), then that (in this bizarre worldview) would not be "forcible" rape.
A woman assaulted physically who submitted to avoid further injury, would not have been "forcibly" raped.
Date rape (under the influence of alcohol or drugs - even administered surreptitiously) would not be "forcible" rape.
Presumably, I can't find it in the news accounts, intercourse with a female under the age of consent, who nevertheless did not resist, would not be "forcible" rape. Anyone pick up that detail?

Apparently, for rape to be considered "forcible," physical strength must have been used actually to achieve penetration, not merely to compel submission.

And yes, God help us all!
What the hell is "forcible rape?"   Isn't all rape forced?   The Ryan/Romney ticket needs to explain themselves.  God Help Us All if these two are elected.
Hey, I'm American.  I'm tired of the U.S. being the laughing stock of the world.
Vera in Montreal - at least you're north of our border! Things are truly crazy down here. Better make room for some immigrants if the likes of Akin get elected!
